Title: De-Centering Eighteenth-Century Political Economy: Rethinking Growth, Wealth, and Welfare in the Swedish Empire

This project challenges conventional narratives of eighteenth-century political economy by shifting the focus from abstract theories to practical concerns and policies aimed at betterment and improvement. Through a comprehensive study of the Swedish Empire, we will reexamine the historical development of political economy, moving beyond modernizing interpretations that impose contemporary methods and models on past debates. By exploring the intersections of growth, wealth, and welfare, we will uncover the ways in which various sites of discursive production – including universities, the Diet, local and colonial governments, and academic journals – contributed to the evolution of political economy.

Our hypothesis is that activities in each of these sites were directed towards improving the organization of state and society and the living conditions of the people. By comparing the Swedish Empire to other cases, we will identify broader patterns and applicability, ultimately providing a more nuanced understanding of the complex and multifaceted nature of early modern political economy. This project will not only revise our understanding of the eighteenth century but also inform contemporary debates on economic development, sustainability, and social welfare. By de-centering dominant narratives and highlighting the practical concerns of historical actors, we will create a more inclusive and historically grounded framework for understanding the evolution of political economy.
